misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges. There is no grade variable, no conditional logic for A–F ranges, and the prompts/outputs are unrelated to the specified grade-calculator task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the required program is one that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them, or they reused an unrelated solution for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use an if-else chain (or similar conditionals) to check which range the grade falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: No variable representing a grade (0–100) is read or stored
Input prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
The output message reports a distance value, not a letter grade
There are no if/else or switch statements to implement grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different homework problems or reuse of a previous 'distance between points' solution instead of implementing the specified grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the current logic with code that reads one numeric grade (e.g., int grade = input.nextInt();) and then uses an if-else ladder to check the grade against the given ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.), printing the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Using conditionals to implement numeric ranges
Designing program input and output to match the task
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, and output clearly correspond to a distance-calculation problem, with no elements related to grades or letter-grade ranges.

evidence.note: The code reads four doubles as coordinates and prints the distance between two points, with no grade input or conditional logic to map grades to letter outputs.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem attempted (Distance Calculation instead of Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator' problem. None of the tasks in the rubric can be evaluated.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code for a different assignment or question that involves calculating the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student needed to implement the logic for the 'Grade Calculator' problem, which involves reading a single numeric grade and using conditional statements to map it to a letter grade.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade.
Code calculates Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt and Math.pow.
Code has no conditional statements (if/else if/else) for grade evaluation.
File/class name suggests a different problem ('DistanceBetweenPoints').
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the assignment prompt, submission of code for the wrong question, or failure to delete and replace previous work.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the assignment instructions carefully and ensure the submitted code implements the correct algorithm (reading a grade and using if/else statements for letter grade mapping).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code exclusively solves the distance formula problem, completely ignoring the Grade Calculator requirements (reading a single grade, using conditional logic).

evidence.note: The class name indicates a different problem is being solved.
The code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) rather than a single numeric grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The central logic calculates the distance formula, which is irrelevant to a grade calculator task.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade as specified. As a result, none of the required grade-related input or conditional logic is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should solve a distance-between-points problem that reads x1, y1, x2, y2 and prints the distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional logic to print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
No conditional statements to map numeric ranges to letter grades
Output describes a distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements or mixing up this task with a different assignment involving distance between points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite main so it reads one numeric grade (e.g., int or double), then use an if/else-if/else chain to check the 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below-60 ranges and print the correct letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program consistently implements a distance calculation workflow, with no trace of grade input or letter-grade mapping.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinate values and calculates a distance instead of reading a single grade and computing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Submission
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator' problem (Q3). This indicates a failure to understand or attempt any of the core requirements of Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirements for the Grade Calculator problem (Q3), or they submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must specifically implement the logic for reading a numeric grade and outputting the corresponding letter grade based on the specified scale.
symptoms: Code calculates distance between points instead of grades.
Input reads four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade (0-100).
No conditional logic (if/else structure) is present for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced focus, misunderstanding the assignment requirements, or submitting an incorrect file for the task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions for Q3 and write a program specifically designed to read one grade and use conditional statements to determine and print the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure (class name, variable names, logic) entirely matches a distance calculation program and contains zero elements related to grade calculation as required by the prompt.

evidence.note: Class name clearly indicates the solution to a different problem.
The input reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of the single numeric grade required by the problem.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
